poem:
Title: Inquiry in the Halls of Learning

In the academic dance of Leeds,
The watchdog sniffs out a puzzling breed –
Franchise students, on courses tread,
By subcontractor's hand they're led.

Questions of quality, tales untold,
In the unfolding fable of student loans.
In the quiet corridors, truths unfold,
Where lessons are bought, not only sold.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Watchdog to investigate ‘franchise student’ provision at Leeds Trinity England’s higher education regulator is to launch its first investigation into “franchise students” enrolled on university courses run by subcontractors, amid concerns about poor quality and potential abuse of student loans. The Office for Students (OfS) said it is investigating how 6,500 students are taught under franchise by subcontractors of Leeds Trinity University, saying it will look at whether the courses are of high quality and". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
